header.abstract: The A.B. Happy Chandler papers (dated 1900-1991, undated; 266.9 cubic feet) contain the personal and political papers of the former Governor and Senator of Kentucky and document his political and legal career.

descriptive_summary.author: Processed by William J. Marshall
descriptive_summary.title: A.B. "Happy" Chandler papers
descriptive_summary.arrangement: Divided into the following series: 1920s, Lieutenant Governor, First Gubernatorial, Senatorial, Commissioner of Baseball, 1950s, Second Gubernatorial, 1960s, 1970s, Family/Personal, Miscellaneous, VIP, News clippings, Speech, Photographs, Tape Recordings, Films, Addendum, Addition. Most series arranged alphabetically by subject and thereunder chronologically.

descriptive_summary.prefercite: 77m1: [identification of item], A.B. Happy Chandler papers, 1900-1991, undated, University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: The public career of Albert B. Happy Chandler began in 1928 and spanned a fifty year period, highlighted by two terms as Governor of Kentucky, six years as United States Senator and a tenure as Commissioner of Baseball.

Albert Benjamin Chandler, son of Joseph Sephus and Callie (Saunders) Chandler, was born July 14, 1898, in Corydon, Kentucky. After graduating from Corydon High School in 1917, Chandler entered Transylvania University in Lexington, Kentucky. In 1921 Chandler graduated with a bachelor's degree in history and political science. Chandler entered Harvard Law School in the fall of 1921, but after one year returned to the University of Kentucky to complete his legal education. While at the University of Kentucky coached women's basketball, football at Versailles High School, was assistant football coach at Centre College in the nineteen-twenties.

Chandler set up a law practice in Versailles, Kentucky, in 1925. The same year he married Mildred Watkins of Keysville, Virginia, a teacher at Margaret Hall School for Girls. They had four children: Marcella, Mimi, Ben and Dan.

Chandler's public career began with his appointment as Master Commissioner of Woodford County in 1928. The next year he was elected state senator representing the twenty-second district. At the 1931 Kentucky Democratic convention Chandler was selected to run as Lieutenant Governor on a ticket with Ruby Laffoon. By this time his political activities had come under the guidance of Ben Johnson and J. Dan Talbott of Bardstown. In the 1931 election he was elected Lieutenant Governor over Republican John C. Worsham, while Ruby Laffoon became Governor.

Chandler and Laffoon split over Laffoon's sales tax bill, and in the Governor's absence from the state in 1935, Chandler called a special session of the legislature to enact a compulsory primary law. This law required that party nominations be made by a primary election and not by a convention, which Laffoon and his supporters might well control. Chandler trailed Tom Rhea in the first primary of 1935 but won the runoff, then defeated Republican King Swope to become the Governor of Kentucky.

Chandler's first gubernatorial administration is known for the reorganization of Kentucky state government. Chandler had the new sales tax repealed and through reorganization, reform, frugality, and higher excise and income taxes, financed far-reaching improvements in schools, roads, health and welfare programs, and penal institutions. The Government Reorganization Act of 1936 created a more efficient administration and Chandler was able to pay off much of the state's debt. Among the most significant innovations were the free textbook program, participation in the federal rural electrification program, establishment of a teachers' retirement system and an old-age assistance program, and the start of a special rural roads program. Although friendly to labor, Chandler opposed closed shops and sit-down strikes, and he sent the National Guard into Harlan County to curb labor-related violence there.

Prohibited by law from succeeding himself as governor, Chandler unsuccessfully challenged Alben Barkley, United States Senate Majority Leader, in the 1938 primary. Chandler resigned as governor, and on October 10, 1939, when Lt. Gov. Keen Johnson succeeded him, Johnson appointed Chandler to the U.S. Senate. In 1940 Chandler won a special election for the rest of Logan's term, and in a controversial 1942 campaign he defeated John Y. Brown, Sr., and won a full six-year term.

In Washington, Chandler usually backed the Roosevelt administration although he opposed some of the New Deal fiscal policies and the decision to give priority to the war in Europe over the Pacific conflict during World War Two. Chandler toured the Aleutian Islands and was instrumental in strengthening U.S. defenses in the Alaskan Area and was one of six senators selected to make a world-wide tour of U.S. military installations in 1943. On November 1, 1945, Chandler resigned from the Senate to become national commissioner of baseball. During the next six years, black players entered the major leagues for the first time and a players' pension fund was established. Chandler's bid for a second contract was defeated by baseball owners in 1951, after which he returned to Versailles, Kentucky, to practice law. He was president of West Virginia Fuel Corporation, belonged to the Boards of Directors of the Coastal States Life Insurance Company and Irving Air Chute Company, and served as president of International Baseball Congress in the early 1950s.

In 1955, Chandler won the Democratic nomination for governor over Bert T. Combs, despite the opposition of many of the party's most powerful leaders. He achieved victory in the gubernatorial election over Republican Edwin R. Denney. In his second term as Governor of Kentucky, Chandler achieved improvements in the highway program using a $100 million bond issue, the schools, and other public institutions. Addition funding went to the public schools' Minimum Foundation Program and the teachers' retirement system. His proudest accomplishment was the establishment of the University of Kentucky Albert B. Chandler Medical Center. He attracted national notice in 1956 when he used state police and National Guardsmen to enforce desegregation in the public schools.

Chandler failed in bids for the nomination for governor in 1963, 1967 and 1971. Two incidents in the late 1980s involving alleged racial slurs led to unsuccessful demands for Chandler's resignation or removal from the board. Chandler died on June 15, 1991, at his home in Versailles and was buried in the cemetery of Pisgah Presbyterian Church in Woodford County, Kentucky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The A.B. Happy Chandler papers (dated 1900-1991, undated; 266.9 cubic feet) contain the personal and political papers of the former Governor and Senator of Kentucky and document his political and legal career. Each series contains personal, political, general, and legal papers plus a subject file. There are also some plaques, certificates, photographs, speeches, phono tapes, films, oral histories, and memorabilia with the collection. Of particular note is the series dealing with Chandler's tenure as the Commissioner of Baseball and the desegragation of baseball.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1920s Series consists of two boxes of material mostly concerning Chandler's law practice and term in the Kentucky General Assembly. The papers are arranged alphabetically by subject and then both chronologically and alphabetically within each file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series, composed of nine boxes, covers the period from December 1931 to December 1935. In addition to his service as Lieutenant Governor, papers in this series reflect Chandler's activities as a private attorney and politician. Files within the series appear alphabetically. Papers of major significance in the series include those pertaining to Acting Governor Chandler's move to enact a primary law for the 1935 gubernatorial race.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The First Gubernatorial Series, which consists of eight files, dates from December 1935 to October 1939, at which time Chandler resigned and was appointed to the United States Senate after the death of M.M. Logan. Arrangement of the files is alphabetical, and folders are arranged alphabetically and/or chronologically therein. The records in this series reflect the governor's activities in the following areas: The vast reorganization of a financially bankrupt state government, Sending the National Guard to Harlan County where the United Mine Workers of America were attempting to organize against the wishes of mine owners, and the challenge of Senate Majority Leader Alben W. Barkley in the 1938 senatorial primary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Senatorial Series, which spans the period of October 1939 to November of 1945, comprises sixteen boxes. A majority of the papers in the series came from Senator Chandler's Versailles office. Unfortunately the material generated from his Washington office is incomplete. The Senatorial Series consists of seven files which are arranged according to significance. Within each file, the papers are arranged chronologically and/or alphabetically. The files are: Important Papers File, Political File, Correspondence, Washington-Versailles Office Correspondence, General Correspondence, Miscellaneous File, Invitation File, Walter W. Mulbry Personal Correspondence.

Chandler, who resigned as governor in 1939 to accept an appointment to the U.S. Senate replacing the late M.M. Logan, was elected in a 1940 special election to the seat to complete Logan's term and was re-elected for a full term in 1942. The Senator was a member of the Military Affairs Committee and was chairman of a sub-committee which visited Alaska and the Aleutian Islands in 1942. In 1943 Chandler made a global tour of U.S. military installations as a member of a Senate inspection team. He also served on the Mines and Mining, Privileges and Elections, Interoceanic Canals, and Judiciary Committees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Commissioner of Baseball Series contains material dating from April 1945 to December 1951. The five files are in an alphabetical arrangement. Within each file, the papers are arranged alphabetically and chronologically.

Chandler accepted the position as Commissioner of Baseball in April of 1945 but continued to serve in the Senate until October of that year. Significant materials in this series include: The August 1946 status of baseball Report of Major League Steering Committee for Submission to the National and American League, Many of the decisions made by the Commissioner, Correspondence with prominent baseball figures, Legal correspondence between Chandler and his attorneys at Covington, Burling and Rublee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boxes 171-186

The 1950s Series consists of seven files covering the period between Chandler's tenure as Commissioner of Baseball and his second term as Governor of Kentucky. These files are arranged alphabetically. Within each file, arrangement is alphabetical and/or chronological.

During this period Chandler was President of the International Baseball Congress, a board member of Coastal State Life Insurance Company and Irvin Air Chute Company, and was president of West Virginia Fuel Corporation. He maintained interest in Kentucky politics and campaigned successfully in 1955 for the gubernatorial nomination without the support of the Democratic party organization. Materials relating to these interests are located in the 1950s Series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Second Gubernatorial Series, largest in the Chandler papers, consists of thirteen files alphabetically arranged: Congratulatory Letters, County File, Executive Orders, General Correspondence, General Files, Governor's Personal File, Department of Highways, Prisoner Correspondence, Department of Public Safety, State Departments File, State Financial Papers, State Governors File, State Organizations File, University of Kentucky. Within the files, arrangement is in alphabetical and/or chronological sequence.

The General Files section affords the best overall view of Chandler's activities during his second term as governor from December 1955 to December 1959. It contains important papers about the 1956 and 1960 Democratic National conventions, the legislature and state politics, as well as material on various state departments and events. Specific pieces of interest in General Correspondence are letters from Charles McCord in regard to the Bank of New York serving as paying agent for Kentucky's road bonds and correspondence between Governor Chandler and Paul Butler concerning the role of the leadership of the Democratic National Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The 1960s Series is composed of four files arranged in alphabetical order. The files are: General Correspondence, Political File, Subject File, University of Kentucky Organization within each file is alphabetical or chronological.

Materials in the Series reflect Chandler's varied activities during the decade of the 1960s. He was twice a candidate for governor. In 1963 he challenged the Bert T. Combs administration's candidate in a bitterly fought Democratic primary. He ran again in the 1967 gubernatorial primary. Chandler was politically active in other state elections and mentioned as a vice-presidential candidate for George Wallace's American Independent Party ticket in 1968. In addition to politics, Chandler retained an interest in sports. He served as commissioner of the Continental Football League from 1965 to 1966. His interest in the University of Kentucky, always strong, resulted in Governor Louie Nunn naming him a member of the Board of Trustees in 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1970s Series comprises two files, Miscellaneous Letters and Subject File. Arrangement of the Miscellaneous Letters is chronological while the Subject File is arranged alphabetically. This Series includes materials from the early years of the decade, 1970-1973. Other materials from the later 1970s are represented in the Addendum 1974-1985.

Chandler, though in his seventies, continued his active participation in state affairs during the 1970s. He completed a four-year term on the University of Kentucky's Board of Trustees in 1970. In 1971 he ran unsuccessfully as an independent candidate for Governor of Kentucky against Republican Tom Emberton and Democrat Wendell Ford. Chandler's practice as an attorney and ownership of the Woodford County, Kentucky, Sun Newspaper continued. In 1977, Chandler was appointed to an unprecedented fourth term on the University of Kentucky's Board of Trustees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Family/Personal Series contains personal correspondence and business records of individual family members, Christmas cards, memorabilia and miscellaneous publications. Material is arranged chronologically within individual family units.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous Series consists of individually wrapped, oversized articles. The Series is divided into several categories: Documents, Memorabilia, Photograph Albums, Pictures, Plaques, Political Cartoons, Scrapbooks. Items within each category are individually numbered.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters from presidents to A.B. Happy Chandler were removed from their original files and placed in the V.I.P. Correspondence file. They are arranged chronologically by president. The V.I.P. Correspondence File contains letters to Chandler from: Roosevelt, Franklin D., Truman, Harry S., Eisenhower, Dwight D., Kennedy, John F., Nixon, Richard M.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twelve boxes arranged in chronological order comprise the Newspaper Clippings File which documents Chandler's life from 1922-1975. His second term as Governor of Kentucky is especially well represented.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Speech File contains addresses delivered by Albert B. Happy Chandler between 1931 and 1970. They are arranged chronologically and identified by subject and/or location. A majority of the speeches are from the 1940s and 1950s when Chandler served as U.S. Senator, Commissioner of Baseball and Governor of Kentucky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Tape Recordings Series contains over 30 recordings including interviews, speeches, and news reports such as the 1955 Gubernatorial Inauguration of Chandler. They date from 1955 to the 1970s and are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material in the Films Series includes 6 black and white or color films dating from 1935 to 1955. These include home movies, film of the 1955 Gubernatorial Inauguration, and newsreels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photograph File contains forty boxes of miscellaneous pictures of Albert B. Happy Chandler and his family dating from 1899 to 1977. They are organized in broad groupings and listed in alphabetical order.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Comprises boxes P1-P40; basic list entered by Ruth Bryan, 6/22/2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material in the Addendum 1974-1985 to the Chandler Collection was added to the collection after it was originally accessioned and processed in 1977. The Addendum contains: Correspondence, Invitations, Speeches, Clippings, Income Tax Forms, Legal Papers, Certificates, Memorabilia, and Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Addition series (dated 1925-1991, undated; 9.76 cubic feet; 15 boxes) comprise correspondence, personal items, publicity items, speeches, clippings, photographs, and memorabilia owned or created by A.B. Chandler or his close relatives.
